message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="STV: Foreword and/or Translator's Preface">
NEW VOTE (replaces previous): Front matter structure for the English edition.

The author may write a Preface later — that's separate. For now, we're deciding about the Foreword and Translator's Preface.

Three options:
A. **Foreword only** (written by an outside scholar/figure)
B. **Foreword + Translator's Preface** (both)
C. **Translator's Preface only** (no foreword)

SINGLE TRANSFERABLE VOTE. Rank all three:

"1st: [A/B/C] — 2nd: [A/B/C] — 3rd: [A/B/C] — Reason: [brief justification]"
</teammate-message>

input.content: 1st: B — 2nd: C — 3rd: A — Reason: Option B (Foreword + Translator's Preface) is strongest. A Foreword by an outside scholar situates the work within broader philosophical discourse and lends it credibility for an anglophone audience unfamiliar with the author — this is especially important for a work that engages Western metaphysics, phenomenology, and Chinese philosophy simultaneously, since a recognized figure can signal to readers from any of those traditions that the text merits serious attention. The Translator's Preface remains essential: it is where we explain governing translation decisions (the 德 virtue/character split, "phenomenal X," our handling of 仁义礼, the block-quote conventions) and orient the reader to the text's unusual structure and methodology. These serve different functions and belong in separate pieces. Option C is my second choice because the Translator's Preface is the more indispensable of the two — we can do without a foreword, but we cannot send the reader into this text without a clear account of our translational choices. A foreword alone (Option A) is weakest because it provides external framing but leaves the reader without guidance on the translation itself, which for a work this terminologically dense would be a significant omission.
input.summary: STV vote: B first, C second, A third

routing.summary: STV vote: B first, C second, A third

content.text: Vote submitted. Ranked **B (Foreword + Translator's Preface)** first — the foreword provides external scholarly framing while the Translator's Preface handles our terminological and methodological apparatus. Ranked C second since the Translator's Preface is the more indispensable component of the two. Awaiting next instructions.
